subheaderHeader: Guide to applying for unemployment benefits
subheaderSubheader: Learn what type of benefits you qualify for and how to apply for them.
subheaderParagraph: If you are out of work or had your hours reduced, you may be eligible to receive unemployment benefits from California’s Employment Development Department (EDD).
subheaderParagraph2: First register or log in at Benefit Programs Online, then apply for unemployment benefits on UI Online℠.

tabTitles.1: What you need before you apply

certification-p1: Certification is the required process of updating the EDD every two weeks with your unemployment status with basic eligibility information:
certification-list1-item1: Are you physically able to work?
certification-list1-item3: Are you ready and willing to accept work immediately?
certification-list1-item5: Did you work and earn wages? If so, how much?
certification-p2: The fastest way to certify is on <2>UI Online</2>. You can also do this by phone by calling 1-866-333-4606, or by mailing the paper form.
tab0-header1: Tips for applying on UI Online
tab0-list1-item1: Everyone (UI and PUA applicants) uses the same form. <2>Register or log in with Benefit Programs Online</2> and click “File New Claim.”
tab0-list1-item2: File a new claim if you have already applied for UI but are eligible for PUA because you are a business owner, independent contractor, self-employed worker, freelancer, or gig worker affected by COVID-19, and you have not already appealed a $0 award notice, been asked to verify your identity, or requested a wage investigation.
tab0-list1-item3: If you are a small business owner, independent contractor, self-employed worker, freelancer, or gig worker, here’s how to answer key questions in the application form:
tab0-list1a-item1: On the Employment History screen when you supply your last employer information, select "No."
tab0-list1a-item2: On the Availability Information page, answer question 7 with "No."
tab0-list1a-item3: On the Disaster Information page, answer question 1a.3 with “You are an independent contractor.” If you got paid in cash, select “None of these options apply to me.”
tab0-list1-item4: If you have run out of benefits, you are unemployed, and your benefit year has expired, reapply for benefits through UI Online.
tab0-list1-item5: If you have run out of benefits but you are still within the one year that your claim is good for, and your benefits:
tab0-list1b-item1: Ran out before February 2, you are probably not eligible for PUA. (You would have to show that you are unemployed because of COVID-19.) You may be eligible for the federal 13-week extension. We will notify you about what to do.
tab0-list1b-item2: Were for weeks you spent unemployed between February 2 and March 21, we will send you a form to fill out to supply information not already in your claim. When you get the form, fill it out and return it.
tab0-list1-item6: If you received your last payment for weeks you were unemployed on or after March 21 and are still within your benefit year, we will automatically extend your claim for 13 weeks. We will notify you that we have done that and when you can certify.
tab0-list1-item7: If you applied for unemployment assistance but didn’t qualify (for example, because you voluntarily quit or you were fired or discharged by your employer), or you are serving a penalty because of false statements on a past claim, you could be eligible for PUA. We will send you a form to fill out to supply information not already in your account. When you get the form, fill it out and return it.
tab0-p1: These benefits are available for California residents. If you are still unsure of your eligibility or what to apply for, apply anyway as soon as you are out of work or had your hours reduced. Complete the application as best you can, and we will follow up with you as soon as possible.
tab0-p2: You may be eligible for regular UI if you have income reported on a W2 and you meet any of these:
tab0-list2-item1: Your employment status has been affected by COVID-19 and you are fully or partially unemployed as a result.
tab0-list2-item2: You are fully or partially unemployed. This includes layoffs, furloughs, reduced wages, or reduced hours. You can still receive unemployment benefits while working, depending on your pay.
tab0-list2-item3: Your child’s school is closed, and you need to miss work to care for them.
tab0-list2-item4: Your previous UI claim has expired.
tab0-p3: If you're already receiving UI, review <2>Receive your benefits</2> to learn how your UI claim may be affected by COVID-19.
tab0-p4: If you are a business owner, independent contractor, self-employed worker, freelancer, or gig worker and only received a 1099 tax form last year, you are most likely eligible for PUA.
tab0-header5: Apply for PUA if your work situation changed because of COVID-19, and you meet any of these:
tab0-list3-item1: You had a definite date to begin work, but the job is no longer available, or you could not reach the job as a direct result of COVID-19.
tab0-list3-item2: You are unable to travel to your job as a direct result of COVID-19.
tab0-list3-item3: You quit your job as a direct result of COVID-19.
tab0-list3-item4: Your workplace is closed as a direct result of COVID-19.
tab0-list3-item5: You are unemployed, partially employed, or unable to work because COVID-19 has forced you to stop working.
tab0-header6: Apply for PUA if you have health issues because of COVID-19, and you meet any of these:
tab0-list4-item1: You have been diagnosed with COVID-19 or are experiencing symptoms and are seeking a medical diagnosis.
tab0-list4-item2: A member of your household has been diagnosed with COVID-19.
tab0-list4-item3: You are caring for a family member or a member of your household who has been diagnosed with COVID-19.
tab0-list4-item4: You are caring for a dependent during the work day because their school or another care facility has closed due to COVID-19.
tab0-list4-item5: Your healthcare provider has told you to self-quarantine because of COVID-19.
tab0-list4-item6: You have become the main income provider due to a COVID-19 death in your household.
tab0-header7: Disability Insurance (DI) or Paid Family Leave (PFL)
tab0-p5: If you’re not eligible for UI, you may be eligible for Disability Insurance or Paid Family Leave. You usually qualify if you paid into the State Disability Insurance program (noted as “CASDI” on paystubs), via taxes.
tab0-list5-item1: If you are unable to perform your normal work duties because you are sick or quarantined, apply for <2>Disability Insurance.</2>
tab0-list5-item2: If you are caring for a family member who is sick, apply for <2>Paid Family Leave.</2>
tab1-header1: Proof of citizenship or authorization to work in the United States
tab1-p1: You will need all of the following:
tab1-list1-item2: California driver license or ID card
tab1-list1-item3: Proof of US citizenship, or a green card, or a visa that allows you to work in the US, or an Alien Registration Number
tab1-p2: You must be authorized to work in the US to receive unemployment benefits. If you are not a US citizen, have information from your employment authorization document ready.
tab1-p3: Your work history affects the amount of benefits you receive each week. Submitting accurate information helps us process your claim faster. You will need:
tab1-list2-item1: Work history from the last 18 months. This includes the name of any companies as they appear on your paycheck, the dates of employment, hours worked per week, the total wages you earned before taxes were taken out (gross wages), hourly rate of pay, and the reason you are no longer working.
tab1-list2-item2: Specific information from your last employer or company. This includes your employer’s name, mailing address, phone number, supervisor’s name, total wages you earned before taxes were taken out (gross wages) for the last week you worked, and the reason for your unemployment.
tab1-list3-item1: If you are a former federal employee, have your Notice to Federal Employees About Unemployment Insurance (Standard Form 8) ready.
tab1-list3-item2: If you served in the military in the last 18 months, have your Certificate of Release or Discharge from Active Duty (DD 214) ready.
tab2-p1: The fastest way to apply for all unemployment benefits is through UI Online. After you have registered for a Benefit Programs Online account, you can get started on UI Online. You can still apply for UI by <4>phone, mail, or fax.
tab2-header2a: Filling out employment information for COVID-19 claims in UI Online
tab2-list1-item1: If you have been laid off or had hours cut back as a direct result of COVID-19, under the first dropdown menu in the Additional Information section, select Laid Off/Lack of Work as your reason for separation. Then select Out of Work Due to COVID-19.
tab2-list1-item2: Submit the first date you were affected by COVID-19. We will back pay you for the weeks you are eligible to receive benefits. PUA supports claims between February 2 and December 26, 2020. Claims between March 29 and July 25, 2020 are eligible for an additional, taxable $600 every week.
tab2-header2b: Tips for applying on UI Online
tab2-p2: These will help your claim get processed faster.
tab2-list2-item2: Check for spelling errors or mismatched employer names.
tab2-list2-item3: Confirm your Social Security number and California Driver’s License or ID number. (Check that this information matches your tax forms.)
tab2-blockquote1: Note: If you’re a business owner, independent contractor, self-employed worker, freelancer, or gig worker, you can complete your employment information under the Additional Information section. Submit your net annual income for last year under the Natural Disasters question.
tab2-header3: If you were previously approved for UI
tab2-p3: Restart your old claim. If your UI application was approved within the past 12 months and you stopped receiving benefits, you don't need to submit a new application. If your claim is more than 12 months old, you will need to file a new claim.
tab3-header1: 1. We'll confirm your application and weekly benefit amount (WBA) via email and postal mail
tab3-list1=item1: You should receive the confirmation of your application within two weeks via postal mail. We'll let you know what your WBA is, based on our wage records. For an initial estimate of your WBA, use our <4>UI benefit calculator.
tab3-list1-item2: You may receive an email confirming that you were automatically registered in UI Online. This allows you to fully access information about your claim and to certify for continued benefits online.
tab3-list1-item3: If you're not automatically registered in UI Online, you’ll receive a notice in the mail with your EDD Customer Account Number. Use the account number to finish registering for full UI Online access.
tab3-p1: If we need more information from you to complete your claim, we may call you or mail you a notice. If we are unable to verify your identity or your wages, our system might determine your estimated WBA to be $0.00. If this happens, we may need more time to process your claim. If you were paid wages during the four quarters shown on your Notice of Unemployment Insurance Award, you should contact the EDD to request a wage investigation.
tab3-header2: For business owners, independent contractors, self-employed workers, freelancers, gig workers:
tab3-p2: If you qualify for PUA, your initial weekly benefit amount will be $167 for claims starting February 2, 2020. Claims between March 29 to July 25, 2020 will have an additional $600. Your total benefits will last for 39 weeks (including any regular UI and extended benefits you might qualify for).
tab3-p3: Once we verify your income, your weekly benefit amount may increase. Any increase will also apply retroactively. We will notify you of any increase you are entitled to receive. <3>Read more about PUA.
tab3-blockquote1: Note: You will be paid benefits from the date you became unemployed as a result of COVID-19, regardless of when you submitted your claim application.
tab3-header3: 2. Certify for your first benefit payment
tab3-list2-item1: Certify your claim in UI Online once you're registered. You will also be required to certify your claim every two weeks.
tab3-list2-item2: You can answer "No" when we ask whether you are looking for work, due to COVID-19. If you meet all other eligibility requirements, you will still receive benefits.
tab3-p7: We understand that it’s a difficult time to look for a job right now. You are currently not required to upload your resume to <3>CalJOBS during the COVID-19 pandemic.
tab4-header1: 1. Look for your EDD Debit Card℠ in the mail
tab4-p1: Benefit payments for Unemployment Insurance, Pandemic Unemployment Assistance (PUA), Disability Insurance, and Paid Family Leave are all made using the EDD Debit Card.
tab4-p2: Typically, it will take about a week after you certify before you receive your first benefit payment. If you applied for PUA, your EDD Debit Card will be issued within 24-48 hours after you submit your application.
tab4-blockquote1: Note: Due to the high volume of claims, it may take a few extra days to receive your EDD Debit Card in the mail.
tab4-p3: To set up direct deposit transfer from your debit card to your bank account, visit the <2>Bank of America EDD Debit Card website</2>.
tab4-p4: For more information on the EDD Debit Card, visit <2>EDD Debit Card</2>.
tab4-list1-item1: If you were issued an EDD Debit Card in the last three years, you will receive your benefit payments on that card. If your card has expired, a new card will automatically be sent to you once funds are available.
tab4-list1a-item1: Note: If you were issued a card before 2015, you must visit <3>Replace my Card or contact Bank of America at 1-866-692-9374 (TTY: 1-866-656-5913) to request a new one.
tab4-list1-item2: If you lost your EDD Debit Card, visit <3>Replace my Card or contact Bank of America at 1-866-692-9374 (TTY: 1-866-656-5913). You do not need to speak to a representative. Choose the “lost or stolen” option in the automated menu. Your new card will arrive 7 to 10 business days from the order date.
tab4-list1-item3: You can download the Bank of America Prepaid Card app from any app store to keep track of your EDD Debit Card payments and balance information.
tab4-list1-item4: Note: Bank of America representatives cannot answer questions about your claim or pending payments.
tab4-header3: 2. Certify your claim every two weeks
tab4-p5: To continue receiving benefit payments, you’ll need to certify your unemployment status every two weeks via UI Online for the fastest and most secure way to obtain benefits.
tab4-header5: All claims from March 29 to July 25, 2020 will include an additional $600 every week
tab4-p8: We will automatically add $600 every week certified to eligible claimants from March 29 to July 25, 2020. These funds are part of the Federal Pandemic Unemployment Assistance (FPUC) program, also referred to as Pandemic Additional Compensation (PAC).
tab4-header6: UI benefit payments have been extended for COVID-19 claims
tab4-p9: We normally provide up to 26 weeks of UI benefits to eligible claimants. Once we have implemented the Pandemic Emergency Unemployment Compensation program (PEUC), you may be eligible to extend your benefits for 13 weeks, for a total of 39 weeks.
tab4-p10: We are still working to implement this program which will take effect retroactively to March 29, 2020. In the interim, individuals who have exhausted their benefits on their regular UI claim may be eligible to receive benefits on a PUA claim.
tab5-p2: More details about what you need to do after you file your claim: <2>COVID-19 Unemployment Insurance Claims</2>
tab5-header2: New unemployment programs from the CARES Act
tab5-p3: These programs expand Unemployment Insurance (UI) benefits by increasing the number of people who are eligible, increasing benefit amounts, and extending the length of the program.
tab5-p4: This expands who can apply for UI, due to COVID-19. This includes business owners, independent contractors, self-employed workers, freelancers, gig workers and people with limited work history. It is also available to people who have exhausted their regular UI claims, are serving penalty weeks on their claim, or whose claim may be disqualified. PUA supports claims between February 2 and December, 2020. <3>Read more about PUA.
tab5-header4: Federal Pandemic Unemployment Compensation (FPUC) or Pandemic Additional Compensation (PAC)
tab5-p5: This provides an additional $600 per week to people receiving UI benefits. It is retroactive for claims between March 29 and July 25, 2020. This $600 benefit is issued every two weeks. You will receive it at the same time as your UI or PUA benefits.
tab5-p6: This provides an additional 13 weeks of benefits for people receiving UI benefits between March 29 and December 26, 2020. California provides up to 26 weeks of UI benefits depending on the amount of your earnings during the four-quarter period on which your claim is based. The CARES Act extends benefits to a total of 39 weeks.
tab5-blockquote1: Note: We are still working to implement the PEUC program. Please continue to monitor our website for instructions on next steps for the PEUC program.
